Implement specimen transport networks to county labs for higher-complexity tests
Introduce maintenance contracts for equipment

coverage_gaps.description: Inadequate capacity at Level 4 county hospitals to deliver basic essential surgical procedures (lack of theatre staffing, anaesthesia, sterilisation, blood transfusion capacity), increasing referrals and delays.

coverage_gaps.description: Weak inter-facility referral systems and limited emergency medical transport (ambulances) leading to delays in time-critical care and poor continuity across levels.

coverage_analysis.service_availability: Available but fragmented and often of variable quality
coverage_analysis.geographic_accessibility: Physically accessible but constrained by hours and capacity
coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: High OOP due to private providers and user fees
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Suboptimal (unregulated private providers, weak referrals)

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Complements child health and NCD clinical gaps by addressing service delivery bottlenecks in dense urban populations rather than clinical protocols.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Accredit and contract quality-assured private clinics to provide PHC services under SHIF
Extend clinic hours and strengthen referral links to county hospitals
Scale community health insurance enrolment and SHIF outreach
service_integration_opportunities: Integrate WASH, nutrition and mental health screening in urban PHC packages
Partner with local NGOs for community mobilization

implementation.county_integration: Counties to create urban health strategies that include informal settlement mapping and provider contracting.
implementation.funding_mechanisms: SHIF contracting of private providers for PHC services; PHC Fund to support extension of public facility hours and CHV stipends.

coverage_gaps.description: Inconsistent service continuity and limited SHIF-recognition for refugees and cross-border populations leading to inequitable access and missed public health surveillance opportunities.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: County health facilities in border counties, refugee camp clinics (national and UN-managed)
kenya_context.population_impact: Refugees, migrants, cross-border pastoralists (counties: Dadaab area, Kakuma, Turkana, Busia, Kisumu border regions)
kenya_context.geographic_scope: Border counties and refugee-hosting counties (Garissa, Turkana, West Pokot, Trans Nzoia, Busia)
kenya_context.current_coverage_level: Variable; formal access to national SHIF-covered services for refugees limited (<30% integration)

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Curative and preventive services for displaced and mobile populations

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: Often subsidized by humanitarian partners but not integrated into SHIF
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Variable; limited surveillance integration

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Differs from clinical disease gaps by addressing inclusion and financing for population groups with special status rather than pure clinical service design.

Strengthen outreach immunization and surveillance in border towns
Harmonize referral pathways between humanitarian clinics and county hospitals
service_integration_opportunities: Integrate refugee camp health data into national HMIS for early detection and response
Joint planning between county and UN/humanitarian health actors

implementation.county_integration: Counties with refugee populations to sign MOUs with national refugee agencies; joint service planning.
implementation.funding_mechanisms: Blended financing: humanitarian donors for immediate needs, SHIF for accredited services, PHC Fund for outreach integration.

coverage_gaps.description: Frequent stock-outs of essential medicines at primary and county levels due to fragmented procurement, distribution bottlenecks and limited buffer stocks.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: All public health facility levels, county procurement systems
kenya_context.population_impact: All service users, with the poorest affected most by OOP purchasing
kenya_context.geographic_scope: Nationwide with acute shortages in remote counties and during supply shocks

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Curative services (essential medicines provision)

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: Expensive when patients buy from private pharmacies
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Suboptimal due to expired/poor storage at times

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Supports all clinical programs by ensuring treatment availability; differs by focusing on systems (procurement/distribution) rather than specific clinical protocols.

Standardize essential medicine lists aligned to SHIF benefits package
Use pooled procurement and framework contracts to stabilize supply

Link CHV reporting on stock-outs to county logistics teams

coverage_gaps.description: Maldistribution and shortages of health workforce cadres at PHC and county levels (nurses, clinical officers, laboratory technicians), with weak incentives for rural deployment and retention.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: All facility levels; county HRH management systems

kenya_context.geographic_scope: Rural counties, ASAL regions, remote wards nationwide

coverage_analysis.service_availability: Limited due to lack of personnel
coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: N/A (service availability constrained)

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Enables clinical services across priorities; different focus on structural HRH solutions rather than disease-specific clinical interventions.

Scale up training and deployment of mid-level and community health cadres

coverage_gaps.description: Fragmented HIS and incomplete routine data capture for service coverage metrics (lack of SHIF-specific service utilization and tariff data), impairing planning and performance-based financing.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: All facility levels; county health information units
kenya_context.population_impact: National policy-makers, counties, purchasers (SHIF) and facility managers
kenya_context.geographic_scope: Nationwide; some counties with better digital adoption
kenya_context.current_coverage_level: Estimated completeness and timeliness of essential service reporting: 60–80% (varies)

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Health systems strengthening (information systems for UHC monitoring)

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: N/A
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Suboptimal for coverage measurement, lacks SHIF-aligned tariffs

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Enables measurement and accountability for clinical and non-clinical gaps; differs by focusing on data systems rather than clinical services.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Define SHIF core coverage indicators and integrate into DHIS2 with facility reporting templates
Capture service tariffs and unit-costs in SHIF contracting database
Train facility staff on reporting completeness and quality
service_integration_opportunities: Link HMIS with logistics, HRH and financial databases for integrated performance dashboards
Use routine data to trigger performance-based payments

coverage_gaps.description: Inadequate SHIF and county financing coverage for routine outpatient management of chronic conditions (medicines, follow-up visits), resulting in OOP costs and poor adherence.

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: Limited - high OOP for medicines and repeated visits
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Suboptimal due to interrupted supplies and follow-up

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Complements NCD and chronic clinical care by addressing financing and continuity rather than clinical protocols or tertiary treatment.

Implement multi-month dispensing of chronic medicines at PHC
Use community delivery models for adherence support

Integrate NCD care with mental health and rehabilitation where relevant

implementation.funding_mechanisms: SHIF to cover routine outpatient chronic care packages; PHC Fund to support CHV-based adherence programs and commodity procurement.

coverage_gaps.description: Insufficient accreditation, contracting and quality assurance mechanisms for the large private and faith-based provider network, limiting SHIF's ability to expand equitable access through purchasing.

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: All categories as delivered by private providers (curative, preventive, diagnostics)

coverage_analysis.service_availability: Available but not integrated into purchaser networks
coverage_analysis.geographic_accessibility: Good in urban areas but quality varies
coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: High OOP in unregulated private sector
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Variable; limited oversight

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Enables system-wide coverage expansion and reduces pressure on public facilities; differs from clinical gaps by focusing on purchasing and regulation.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Accelerate private provider accreditation and SHIF contracting with standardized tariffs
Develop bundled payment models for common PHC and diagnostic services
Quality improvement and supervision programmes for contracted private providers
service_integration_opportunities: Use private sector to expand diagnostic and PHC access in urban slums and peri-urban areas
Coordinate referrals between private and public sectors
infrastructure_requirements: IT connectivity for claims submission, provider directories, contractual frameworks

implementation.county_integration: Counties to maintain provider registries and support accreditation processes; implement local contracting where appropriate.
implementation.funding_mechanisms: SHIF as primary purchaser; PHC Fund to co-fund outreach; performance-based payments and quality-linked incentives.

coverage_gaps.description: Limited ambulatory/home-based care models for chronic and palliative patients leading to unnecessary admissions and high service costs.

kenya_context.population_impact: Chronic patients, palliative care patients, older adults with limited mobility

Introduce SHIF reimbursement codes for home visits and telehealth follow-up
Training for caregivers and CHVs in basic clinical monitoring

coverage_gaps.description: Inconsistent adoption of standard clinical guidelines and QA processes at county and facility levels leading to variable quality of care and avoidable complications.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: All facility levels, county QA units, regulatory bodies
kenya_context.population_impact: All patients interacting with public and contracted private facilities

kenya_context.current_coverage_level: Proportion of facilities implementing clinical guidelines and QA cycles: 40–60%

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Quality assurance for curative and preventive services

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: N/A
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Suboptimal in many facilities

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Supports improved outcomes across clinical priorities but is distinct by addressing systems, governance and provider behaviour.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Roll out standardised county QA packages, clinical checklists and morbidity/mortality review processes
Link QA performance to SHIF contracting and reimbursements
Provide regular mentorship and supportive supervision
service_integration_opportunities: Use existing disease programs (HIV, TB, MCH) QA frameworks to mainstream standards
Facility-level QI collaboratives across counties
infrastructure_requirements: Training resources, QA tools, data dashboards and feedback loops

implementation.funding_mechanisms: PHC Fund for training and supervision; SHIF to condition part of payments on quality metrics.

coverage_gaps.description: Advanced imaging (CT, MRI, specialized ultrasounds) and structured X-ray services are concentrated at tertiary centres with limited access or high costs for county populations; primary level imaging (basic X-ray) also insufficient in many counties.

kenya_context.population_impact: Patients with trauma, surgical, oncology, and chronic conditions requiring imaging, particularly in rural counties
kenya_context.geographic_scope: Major urban centres have capacity; many counties lack functional basic imaging
kenya_context.current_coverage_level: Functional basic imaging at county level: 40–60%; advanced imaging accessible <20% without referral

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Curative services (medical imaging and investigations)

coverage_analysis.service_availability: Limited for both basic and advanced imaging
coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: Expensive when accessing private tertiary centres
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: Variable due to lack of trained radiographers and maintenance

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Supports surgical, emergency and specialist care but focuses on access and affordability of imaging services rather than clinical procedures themselves.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Equip priority Level 4 hospitals with digital X-ray and basic ultrasound and train operators
Establish referral imaging networks with subsidised access for SHIF-enrolled patients
Implement maintenance and QA contracts for imaging equipment
service_integration_opportunities: Integrate imaging referrals into tele-radiology reading services from Level 5-6 hospitals
Bundle imaging with surgical and trauma pathways (e.g., trauma hubs)
infrastructure_requirements: Imaging equipment, PACS/tele-radiology links, trained technicians

implementation.county_integration: Counties to prioritize imaging investments in Level 4 hospitals; create referral and subsidisation policies for advanced imaging.
implementation.funding_mechanisms: PHC Fund for basic imaging at Level 4; SHIF to reimburse advanced imaging at accredited centres; public-private partnerships for equipment financing.

coverage_gaps.description: Absence of consistent published tariffs and transparent costing for SHIF-covered services (policy data shows zero tariffs entries), undermining purchaser-provider contracting, price setting and patient financial predictability.

kenya_context.service_delivery_platform: National SHIF purchasing, county providers, private providers
kenya_context.population_impact: SHIF beneficiaries, uninsured patients negotiating prices, counties setting provider payment rates
kenya_context.geographic_scope: Nationwide
kenya_context.current_coverage_level: Tariff transparency and alignment largely absent in SHIF policy dataset (0 tariffs recorded)

coverage_gaps.who_essential_services: Health systems strengthening (purchasing and financial protection)

coverage_analysis.financial_accessibility: Reduced by unpredictable charges
coverage_analysis.quality_adequacy: N/A

coverage_gaps.clinical_integration: Enables scale-up of many clinical services by providing clear price signals and incentives; differs by focusing on governance and purchasing levers.

immediate_coverage_expansion: Conduct costing studies for the SHIF service package (PHC, surgical, diagnostics) and publish standard tariffs
Establish provider payment schedules and transparent reimbursement processes
Develop simple patient-facing benefit entitlements and co-payment rules

Use tariff data to inform county budgeting and provider contracting

implementation.county_integration: Counties to adopt standard tariffs in county contracting and ensure public communication on entitlements.
implementation.funding_mechanisms: National SHIF budget to fund costing exercises; PHC Fund to pilot tariff linked payments at facility level.
implementation.timeline_realistic: 6–12 months for costing and publication; phased adoption 12–36 months

coverage_gaps.description: CHV programme underfunded and inconsistently supervised, limiting community-level prevention, referrals, defaulter tracing and linkages to PHC services.

Equip CHVs with job aids, mobile reporting tools and commodity kits

Integrate CHV incentives with SHIF performance metrics at facility level
infrastructure_requirements: CHV training centres, mobile phones/tablets, supervision transport

implementation.county_integration: Counties to formalize CHV cadres within county HR and financing structures with clear supervision lines.
